text: The researchers examined weather data from sensors in both the Pacific and throughout the Eastern US between 1982 to 2015 , finding that the Pacific Extreme Pattern was a strong predictor of heat waves .
When the pattern emerges , there is a 1 in 4 chance that the Eastern US will experience extreme heat in 50 days .
A new study , published today in Nature Geoscience , reveals that heat waves arise in a predictable pattern roughly 40 to 50 days after an event called the Pacific Extreme Pattern .
The authors of the study emphasize that the heat waves are a combination of heat in the Pacific with low rain in the east .
Extreme heat waves like the one that hit the Eastern US in 2012 , leaving at least 82 dead , do n't just come out of nowhere .
What 's remarkable about this study is that it might pave the way for other kinds of extreme weather prediction as well .
Scientists have just discovered a bizarre pattern in global weather .

They write , " The results presented here link two previously identified precursors to hot days-precipitation deficits and an anomalous atmospheric wave train - with the occurrence of [ Pacific Extreme Pattern ] .
During a Pacific Extreme Pattern , a large area of the Pacific north of Hawaii experiences unusual temperatures both at the water 's surface and far above it in the atmosphere .

These unusual temperature patterns create a wave of weather effects that sweep over most of the US , then stop over the humid inland eastern region , creating a high pressure zone that brings clear skies and oppressive heat .
It is exciting that there is some skill demonstrated as far out as 50 days as this also gives us hope for linkages to other extreme weather events .
The effect is intensified if there has been little rain in the east as well .
There 's a 1 in 2 chance that they 'll experience it in 40 days .
" That 's one train you do n't want to be riding when summer comes .
Given that the Eastern US has a high population as well as many agricultural regions that are breadbaskets for the nation , this kind of long-range prediction could be lifesaving .
